Question_1.Context: The study investigated the response of tobacco plants to Ralstonia solanacearum infection. The microbial communities in the root and stem compartments were analyzed.
Question_1.Question: What was observed in the microbial community diversity of tobacco root and stem compartments upon R. solanacearum infection?
Question_1.D: Shift from bacteria to fungi dominance
Question_1.Source: An obvious reduction of community diversity and changes of microbial composition were observed in tobacco root and stem compartments upon R. solanacearum infection.

Question_2.Context: The study focused on the defense responses of tobacco plants to bacterial wilt disease caused by Ralstonia solanacearum.
Question_2.Question: Which defense signaling pathways were significantly activated in tobacco roots and stems with R. solanacearum infection?
Question_2.Source: Key genes participating in plant defense signaling pathways of JA (jasmonic acid) and SA (salicylic acid) were significantly activated in tobacco root and stem with R. solanacearum infection.

Question_3.Context: The study explored the activities of defense enzymes in tobacco plants in response to Ralstonia solanacearum infection.
Question_3.Question: What was the trend observed in the activities of defense enzymes in diseased roots and stems compared to healthy plants?
Question_3.D: Shift from enzymatic to non-enzymatic defense mechanisms
Question_3.Source: Activities of defense enzymes of SOD, PPO, POD, PAL, CAT and β-1,3-GA in root and stem compartments in diseased plants were significantly higher than those in healthy plants.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the effects of inoculating beneficial endophytic Burkholderia ASV_550 on tobacco plants.
Question_4.Question: What was the impact of Burkholderia ASV_550 inoculation on tobacco plants in the presence of R. solanacearum?
Question_4.D: No effect on plant defense system
Question_4.Source: Inoculation of beneficial Burkholderia ASV_550 in soils greatly enhanced the tobacco defense system and reduced the disease incidence when the pathogen was present.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the recruitment of beneficial microbes in tobacco roots and stems upon Ralstonia solanacearum infection.
Question_5.Question: Which bacterial genus was significantly enriched in diseased roots compared to diseased stems?
Question_5.Source: Bacterial genera of Burkholderia were significantly enriched in the root compartment compared to the stem compartment.

Question_6.Context: The study focused on the antagonistic activities of endophytic bacteria against Ralstonia solanacearum.
Question_6.Question: Which bacterial strain showed the strongest antagonistic activity against R. solanacearum?
Question_6.Source: Burkholderia ASV_550 showed the strongest antagonistic activities in vitro against R. solanacearum.

Question_7.Context: The study evaluated the expression of key genes related to plant defense signaling pathways.
Question_7.Question: Which gene involved in the salicylic acid signaling pathway showed increased expression in diseased roots and stems?
Question_7.Source: Expression of NtNPR1, a gene involved in the salicylic acid signaling pathway, was enhanced in both diseased root and stem compartments.

Question_8.Context: The study analyzed the impact of Ralstonia solanacearum infection on the microbial composition in tobacco root and stem compartments.
Question_8.Question: Which fungal phylum was more abundant in the root compartment compared to the stem compartment?
Question_8.Source: The relative abundance of fungal Ascomycota was higher in the root compartment compared to the stem compartment.

Question_9.Context: The study investigated the effects of pathogen invasion on the microbial composition in tobacco root and stem compartments.
Question_9.Question: Which microbial community showed a greater influence on the bacterial community structure than bacterial wilt disease?
Question_9.Source: The endophytic compartment (root) exerted a greater effect on the whole bacterial community than bacterial wilt disease.

Question_10.Context: The study explored the recruitment of beneficial microbes in diseased tobacco plants.
Question_10.Question: What was the trend observed in the microbial diversity of diseased roots compared to healthy roots?
Question_10.D: Shift from bacteria to fungi dominance
Question_10.Source: An obvious reduction of community diversity and changes of microbial composition were observed in tobacco root compartments upon R. solanacearum infection.
